#!/bin/bash
function updatepk() { if [ ! -z $1 ]; then if [ -e /var/run/yum.pid ];then exit 10 fi result=`yum -y update $1 2>&1` status=$? commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: command not found"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: No such file or directory"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "lock /var/run/yum.pid"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "/var/run/yum.pid: another copy is running"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "There was an error communicating with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "This system is not registered with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "No Repositories Available to Set Up"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "Error Class Code: 9 Error Class Info: Invalid System Credentials"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isscriptletfailed=`echo $result | grep -E "error:" | grep -E "scriptlet failed, exit status 255"` if [ "$isscriptletfailed" != "" ]; then exit 6 fi if [ $status -ne 0 ];then exit 7 fi fi } updatepk kexec-tools
exit 0

Vulnerability.Title: kexec-tools bug fix update
Vulnerability.Description: The kexec-tools packages contain the /sbin/kexec binary and utilities that together form the user-space component of the kernel's kexec feature. The /sbin/kexec binary facilitates a new kernel to boot using the kernel's kexec feature either on a normal or a panic reboot. The kexec fastboot mechanism allows booting a Linux kernel from the context of an already running kernel. This update fixes the following bugs: After CPU or memory hot-add or hot-remove, the kdump service needs to be restarted to reconfigure Executable and Linkable Format (ELF) information which is then passed to the second kernel. However, after hot-removing CPU, the kexec command previously failed with the following error message: "/sys/devices" does not exist. Sysfs does not seem to be mounted. Try mounting sysfs. An upstream patch has been implemented to fix this bug. As a result, the kdump service now successfully restarts and kexec no longer fails in the aforementioned scenario. (BZ#1114636) Prior to this update, the kdump module did not handle the IPADDR variable in the ifcfg configuration file correctly. Consequently, kdump failed to produce the vmcore file using a NFS filesystem. The underlying source code has been patched, and kdump now produces the vmcore file as intended. (BZ#1116067) Users of kexec-tools are advised to upgrade to these updated packages, which fix these bugs. Note for remediation: Please disable the SELinux for RHEL 4/5 when repairing, or some rpm packages will fail to install.
